Event 9 (visual) shows a Microsoft Support page opening but staying blank during loading (sub-event 5). Finally, Event 9 (audio) includes the narrator suggesting to use the provided links to download drivers and summarizing ways to solve the problem (sub-event 6). Determining this order requires the audio cues about restarting and using links (Events 8 and 9) together with the visual sequence of uninstalling, scanning, and web navigation (Events 6, 7, and 9).

question:

question:

(6) Slides on "GENERATING DATABASE SCHEMAS" and "STORED PROCEDURES" appear as the speaker explains invoking procedures and points to a spec link.
gold_reasoning: Event 4 transitions from Entity Manager code to a "Metamodel API" title (visual) while the speaker explains using Jakarta Persistence to obtain metadata (audio), so (1) is first. Event 5 then continues the metamodel topic, with the narrator stating auto-generated metamodel classes with trailing underscores and attributes per field (audio) as "UserID"/"UserName" examples appear onscreen (visual), matching (2). Event 6 introduces the CRUD theme visually ("Creating Database Records," CRUD logos) and the speaker explains creating records via entity classes (audio), giving (3). Next, Event 9 shows the "SQL RESULT SET MAPPING" header and diagrams (visual) while @SqlResultSetMapping and distinct field mapping are described (audio), matching (4). Event 10 follows with the "Performing Updates & Deletes" slide and merge() arrow (visual) and the distinctive abrupt sound effect (audio), so (5) is next. Finally, Event 11 covers "GENERATING DATABASE SCHEMAS" and then "STORED PROCEDURES" (visuals) as the speaker explains invoking procedures and concludes by pointing to the specification link (audio), giving (6) last. Therefore the order is 1 -> 2 -> 3 -> 4 -> 5 -> 6.

question:
Reconstruct the correct chronological order of these tutorial moments:
(1) The host introduces himself as “Chi World” and promises to get straight to the point.
(2) While sketching, he exclaims “What is that? Oh shit! What is that?” then says it’s about coloring and to select everything and merge lines.
(3) He says to “expand appearance,” go to Pathfinder, and click “merge” to unify the design, with hip‑hop music in the background.
(4) He duplicates the layer, locks the top line‑work layer so shadows fall underneath, and a fart sound effect plays.
(5) He picks a golden yellow and drags a rectangle over the line work.
(6) He right‑clicks, goes to Arrange, and sends the color shape to the back.
(7) He instructs to highlight everything and merge it together to make it one, over background hip‑hop music.
gold_reasoning: From event 0 (audio), the speaker opens with “Chi World” and getting straight to the point, which must precede all tutorial steps (sub‑event 1). In event 1 (audio+visual), he is still sketching the face while exclaiming “What is that? Oh shit! What is that?” and then instructs to select everything and merge lines—this precedes the more specific Pathfinder steps (sub‑event 2). Event 2 (audio) explicitly mentions “expand appearance” and clicking “merge” in Pathfinder with hip‑hop music present, refining the earlier merging instruction (sub‑event 3). Event 3 (visual+audio) shows the duplication of the layer and locking the top line‑work layer; the unique fart sound effect anchors this moment in time (sub‑event 4). Next, event 4 (audio+visual) has him choose a golden yellow and drag a rectangle over the line work (sub‑event 5), which must occur before event 5 (audio+visual), where he right‑clicks Arrange → Send to Back (sub‑event 6). Finally, event 6 (audio) continues “after you send the color to the back… highlight everything… merge it together,” again with background hip‑hop, making this the last step in this set (sub‑event 7). The ordered sequence is 1 -> 2 -> 3 -> 4 -> 5 -> 6 -> 7.

question:

NaCl using Pt electrodes," and the audio mentions "platinum electrode," establishing the NaCl/Pt introduction (sub-event 1). question:
Reconstruct the correct chronological order of the following sub-events from the first titration run. Use both what is seen and what is said to determine the sequence.
(1) The speaker introduces the vinegar titration and mentions they will prime a burette.
(2) Distilled water is used to coat the sides, and liquid is poured into a beaker labeled WASTE.
(3) The burette is primed and an initial reading of 0.5 mL is announced.
(4) Five drops of phenolphthalein are added to the flask on the stir plate.
(5) The burette is opened and early color changes are not yet persistent.
(6) A faint pink becomes more persistent, and additions are slowed to drops.
(7) The equivalence point is reached; a very light pink is observed and the final burette reading of 42.1 is recorded.
gold_reasoning: Event 0 (audio) is the clear start: the speaker introduces the titration and explicitly says they will prime a burette. Event 1 then shows the rinse/priming prep visually with the WASTE-labeled beaker while the audio mentions using distilled water to coat the sides—this establishes the pre-priming step. Event 2 (audio) specifically describes priming the burette and gives the initial reading of 0.5 mL, which can only be placed here based on the spoken number; the visuals show the NaOH setup but the exact timing relies on audio. Event 3 (audio, supported by visuals of a flask on a stir plate) adds five drops of phenolphthalein and signals the start of titration. Event 4 (audio) describes opening the burette and noting that early color changes are not persistent. Event 5 (audio) notes the color becoming more persistent and slowing to dropwise addition; this aligns with on-screen text seen in the video around this time warning about the stopcock, tying in visual confirmation that they are close to endpoint. Finally, Event 6 (audio) states the equivalence point with a very light pink and records the final burette reading of 42.1. Determining this order requires audio (intro, numeric readings, phenolphthalein, color-change commentary) and visuals (WASTE beaker rinse step, stir plate use, on-screen text), making B the only correct sequence.

question:
Reconstruct the correct chronological order of the following sub-events as they occur in the video. Use both spoken content and visuals to determine the sequence.
(1) On the regular grid, the narrator discusses group 18 "noble gases" as non-reactive, noting how this affected their discovery.
(2) The narrator says group 1 (excluding hydrogen) are the "alkali metals," very reactive and not found alone in nature.
(3) While a circular display is shown, the narrator introduces a spiral table alternative and explains connections among hydrogen, halogens, alkali metals, and noble gases.
(4) The display shifts to a circular periodic table with color-coded labels as the narrator identifies transition and inner transition metals.
(5) The narrator names group 2 as the "alkaline earth metals," pretty reactive but more stable than group 1.
(6) The narrator states group 17 elements are the "halogens" and mostly diatomic.
gold_reasoning: The vocabulary sequence begins on the standard grid: first, the narrator names group 1 as the alkali metals (excluding hydrogen) and emphasizes their reactivity (event 9), which is sub-event 2. Next, the narrator describes group 2 as the alkaline earth metals, "pretty reactive" but more stable (event 10), sub-event 5. Then group 18 noble gases are covered as non-reactive with discovery implications (event 11), sub-event 1. Afterward, group 17 halogens are introduced as mostly diatomic (event 12), sub-event 6. The visual then transitions to a circular periodic table with labeled regions while the narration identifies transition and inner transition metals (event 12), sub-event 4. Finally, over that non-grid visualization, the narrator discusses an alternative spiral arrangement and clarifies relationships among hydrogen, halogens, alkali metals, and noble gases (event 13), sub-event 3. Establishing this order requires audio references to the specific group names/numbers and their properties (events 9–12), plus the visual change to a circular layout before the subsequent spiral-table commentary (events 12–13).

question: Reconstruct the correct chronological order of the following sub-events from the video. Use both the visuals and the audio cues to determine the timeline: (1) Denatured alcohol is poured as the speaker warns about volatiles under a hood; a door closes. (2) Hands are washed under running water while the speaker says to clean chemicals off hands and to mix only when instructed. (3) Opening shows correct pouring labeled "CORRECT" while organ music is cut off by a shattering glass sound. (4) A bottle labeled 18M H2SO4 is poured as the instructor says, "Add the acid to the water, never the reverse." (5) Boiling and splashing are heard as "INCORRECT" appears when water is added to acid. (6) The speaker says to notify the teacher to clean up spills and to clean up when finished, followed by credits over a low hum.
gold_reasoning: Event 0 starts the film: visually we see proper pouring with a green "CORRECT" label and the title context, while the audio features somber organ music abruptly interrupted by shattering glass as the instructor begins safety rules. Next, Event 2 provides the acid–water rule: we see the 18M H2SO4 bottle and hear the explicit instruction "Add the acid to the water, never the reverse." Event 3 follows with the demonstration of what happens if the rule is broken: the visual shows "INCORRECT" and the audio provides boiling/splashing, prefaced by the speaker's warning about not following the rule. After the mixing segment, Event 6 addresses volatile chemicals: visually the denatured alcohol and fume hood context appear, and the audio warns to work under a hood, ending with a door closing sound that anchors this segment. Event 10 then shows handwashing: visually hands under running water and on-screen text about mixing only when told; the audio reinforces cleaning chemicals off hands and the rule about mixing. Finally, Event 14 closes the video: the audio instructs to notify the teacher for spills and to clean up when finished, and the credits roll over a sustained low-frequency hum. This combined sequence (3 -> 4 -> 5 -> 1 -> 2 -> 6) uses both visuals (labels, actions, credits) and audio (shattering glass, boiling/splashing, door closing, humming, spoken instructions) to fix the timeline.

question: Reconstruct the correct chronological order of the following sub-events from the experiment: (1) Adds benzyl chloride to the hexamine solution on the hot plate. (2) Starts reflux; boiling intensifies as water reaches boiling. (3) Sees distinct layers and crystals forming in the condenser after the initial eruption. (4) Opens the valve to separate the organic layer for further processing. (5) Pours in 150 mL concentrated HCl, causing thick fog; plans immediate distillation. (6) After distillation, notes about one-third product loss and neutralizes HCl with water/CaCO3.
gold_reasoning: Event 1 (audio) explicitly states adding “75 milliliters of benzol chloride” to the hexamine solution, while the visual shows pouring into a flask on a hot plate, so (1) must occur first. Event 2 (audio) directs to “start stirring and reflux for a few hours,” and the visual shows vigorous boiling near 300 mL, so the reflux escalation (2) follows the mixing. Event 3 (audio) reports distinct layers and crystals in the condenser after the initial eruption; visually, we see the heated beaker and transfer setup, placing (3) after the reflux begins. Event 4’s visual shows the valve being adjusted to separate the organic layer, and the audio explains the purpose (neutralize amines, hydrolyze benzal chlorides), so separation (4) logically follows observing layers. Event 6 (visual overlay “150 ml conc. HCl” and distillation apparatus) plus audio noting thick fog upon acid addition shows that the HCl addition and plan to distill (5) occurs next. Finally, Event 7 (audio) mentions that after distillation there was a loss of about a third (~25 mL) and neutralization with water/CaCO3; visuals show further reflux with another 150 mL HCl and separatory work, so the post‑distillation loss/neutralization (6) is last. Only sequence B uses both the audio cues (what was added, reflux instructions, fog, product loss) and the visuals (boiling, condenser crystals, valve separation, HCl overlay, distillation setup) to align the correct timeline.

question: Reconstruct the correct chronological order of the following sub-events concerning impurity handling and analysis: (1) Adjusts the distillation setup and remarks the distilled sample has a spicy smell with an overwhelming impurity. (2) Separates and dries benzaldehyde with calcium sulfate, obtaining about 18 mL. (3) States he intentionally tried to remove the impurity but couldn’t. (4) Places benzaldehyde in the freezer; crystals form at −25 °C but filtering doesn’t fix the smell. (5) Observes no liquid at about 10 °C and calls the oxidation rate impressive. (6) Reports a failed vacuum distillation attempt to remove the impurity and ends the update.
gold_reasoning: Event 8 combines visuals of a distillation apparatus with audio reporting a spicy taste/smell and a dominant impurity in the distilled sample, so (1) initiates the sequence. Event 9 visually shows separations/drying and stirring, while the audio quantifies the outcome (about 18 mL) and mentions drying with calcium sulfate, placing (2) next. Event 10 (audio) contains the explicit statement that he purposefully tried to remove the impurity but couldn’t; the visual shows a measuring cylinder (~20 units), suggesting this reflection follows the drying/yield step, so (3) follows (2). Event 11 visuals show freezer handling, a cloth-covered container, and filtering paraphernalia, while the audio specifies crystals at −25 °C and that filtering didn’t help the smell, making (4) the next step in probing the impurity. Event 12 (audio) adds that at ~10 °C there was no liquid left and calls the oxidation rate impressive, while visuals again show freezer handling and a lab setup, placing (5) after the −25 °C trial. Finally, Event 13 (visuals of a vacuum distillation rig and the hydrogen peroxide bottle; overlay notes further usability) aligns with the audio admitting a failed vacuum distillation attempt and wrapping up with “see you later,” clearly making (6) the concluding step. Only sequence A aligns these audio markers (spicy smell, yield, failed removal, crystallization details, oxidation observation, final failed vacuum distillation) with the visual anchors (distillation apparatus, drying/separation, freezer scenes, concluding apparatus) to reconstruct the correct timeline.

question:

(1) Title card shows "Heating with addition of reagents."

In event 0, the green screen title “Heating with addition of reagents” appears first (sub-event 1, visual), followed by the female narrator describing the Claisen adapter and condenser placement (sub-event 2, audio). Finally, event 3 shows the title “Reflux with removal of gases” (sub-event 7, visual), followed by narration on using a fume hood or gas takeoff adapter with gentle vacuum (sub-event 8, audio). Thus, using both visuals (title cards from events 0,1,2,3) and narration (specific technique instructions in the same events), the correct order is 1 -> 2 -> 3 -> 4 -> 5 -> 6 -> 7 -> 8.

question: Reconstruct the correct chronological order of these sub-events from the video: (1) Glowing charcoal briquettes are shown as the speaker contrasts coals with controlled heating. (2) A person lifts a saucepan lid on the stove while the speaker explains the lid’s role in not letting solvent boil away. (3) A hand places a water condenser on the bench as the speaker introduces condensers for catching and cooling vapors. (4) On a whiteboard, arrows are drawn up and down a tall sketch as the speaker explains vapor rises, cools, and drips back. (5) The speaker warns about tygon tubing melting on a hot plate as the person adjusts connected tubes on the setup. (6) The closing department logo appears as the speaker says you should now understand how to reflux with microscale glassware.
gold_reasoning: - From event_id 1, the visual of glowing charcoal appears while the audio explicitly contrasts hot coals with more reliable heating, which precedes the pot/lid demonstration. Later in the same segment, we see the person lift the saucepan lid as the speaker discusses a lid’s function to keep solvent from boiling away, so (1) comes before (2). - Event_id 2 then shows a hand placing a condenser on the bench while the audio introduces condensers for catching and cooling vapors, placing (3) after the stove segment. - Event_id 3 follows with the whiteboard drawing; visually, arrows are added to the sketch while the audio explains vapor rising, cooling, and dripping back, making (4) next. - Event_id 5 then brings safety cautions; visually the person adjusts tubing while the audio warns about tygon tubing near a hot plate, so (5) follows. - Finally, event_id 6 concludes with the department logo visually and the speaker stating the viewer should now understand how to reflux with microscale glassware, making (6) last. Combining the visuals (charcoal, lid lift, condenser placement, whiteboard arrows, tubing adjustments, final logo) with the spoken sequence (coals vs controlled heat, lid function, condenser intro, reflux cycle, safety cautions, closing statement) yields the order 1 -> 2 -> 3 -> 4 -> 5 -> 6.

question: Reconstruct the correct timeline of these sub-events from the lecture’s opening through the early theory segment. Use both the narration and visuals. Sub-events (shuffled): (1) Graphs appear as he lists UV-Vis, IR, and rotational spectroscopy. (2) Upbeat intro music plays before the speaker introduces the spectroscopy series. (3) A brown object and a red wave appear as he says the particle model is poor and waves are a better (but imperfect) model. (4) The ‘spectroscopy’ definition slide appears as he explains energy transforming in molecules. (5) Two red wavy lines are shown as he defines light as oscillating electric and magnetic fields. (6) A red wave enters a complex molecular diagram as he discusses electric-field interactions and says magnetic ones will be in NMR later.
gold_reasoning: Event 0 is first because the audio starts with upbeat intro music and the speaker’s introduction, while the visuals show the title screen (sub-event 2). Event 1 follows: the audio defines spectroscopy and describes energy transformation as the definition slide is shown (sub-event 4). Event 2 comes next: the audio critiques the particle model and suggests waves, while visually a brown object and a red sinusoid appear (sub-event 3). Event 3 follows: the audio defines light as oscillating electric and magnetic fields, and the visuals show two red wavy lines (sub-event 5). Event 4 then extends the idea by discussing photon–molecule electric-field interactions and postponing magnetic interactions to NMR; simultaneously, a red wave enters a complex molecular diagram (sub-event 6). Finally, Event 5: the audio lists UV-Vis, IR, and rotational spectroscopy while graphs with peaks are shown (sub-event 1). Hence, the correct order is 2 -> 4 -> 3 -> 5 -> 6 -> 1.

question:
Reconstruct the correct timeline of the lesson by ordering these sub-events:
(1) The speaker defines a meso compound as having an internal plane of symmetry while the boy writes “meso compound” on the board.
(2) The speaker greets and announces the topic “meso compounds and diastereomers,” with “180°” visible on the whiteboard.
(3) The speaker introduces “diastereomers,” and the board now shows “Diastereomers” with OH and Br labels.
(4) The board shows “Enantiomer” and “Achiral” as the speaker explains mirror images and rotations, noting multiple chiral centers don’t guarantee overall chirality.
(5) The speaker says “this is not a meso compound” because it has a point of symmetry, while a diagram labeled A, B, C is on the board.
(6) The speaker mentions “ten chiral centers,” thanks viewers, asks to subscribe, and signs off with “bye,” as the scene moves to a split-screen with graphics.
gold_reasoning: Chronology is established by combining what is heard and what is seen across events 0, 1, 2, 3, 5, and 9. First (event 0), the audio opens with a greeting and the topic “meso compounds and diastereomers,” while visually the boy stands by the whiteboard showing repeated “180°” (sub-event 2). Next (event 1), the speaker discusses mirror images/rotations and the board visibly shows “Enantiomer” and “Achiral” (sub-event 4). Then (event 2), she defines a meso compound with an internal plane of symmetry; visually the boy writes “meso compound” above the structure (sub-event 1). After that (event 3), she clarifies “this is not a meso compound” due to a point of symmetry, with the A–B–C diagram on the board (sub-event 5). Subsequently (event 5), she moves on to introduce “diastereomers,” and visually the board now bears “Diastereomers” with OH/Br (sub-event 3). Finally (event 9), the speaker mentions “ten chiral centers,” delivers the wrap-up asking to subscribe, and says “bye,” while the video shows the concluding split-screen graphic (sub-event 6). Therefore the correct order is 2 -> 4 -> 1 -> 5 -> 3 -> 6.

question:
Reconstruct the correct chronological order of the following sub-events from the tutorial. Use both what is said and what is shown to decide the sequence.
(1) A single bond is converted to a triple bond, and the narrator names the product ethyne.
(2) The narrator greets and presents the tutorial’s learning objectives on title slides.
(3) The text tool is used to type "ethane", "ethene", and "ethyne" below the structures.

gold_reasoning: Audio in event 0 opens with a greeting and states the learning objectives, matching the title slides visually (event_id 0), so (2) must be first. Next, the audio in event 2 instructs copying and pasting the ethane structure and mentions the visible single bond, while the screen shows multiple ethane copies (event_id 2), so (4) follows. The text labeling step is explicitly instructed next (event_id 5) with the text tool and names appearing under the structures, so (3) follows. Finally, the narrator introduces tetrahedral geometry and instructs pressing Ctrl+A to move objects (event_id 6), which comes after the naming, so (6) is last. Both audio cues (what operation is being described and the names “ethene/ethyne”) and visual confirmations (single/double/triple bonds and labels appearing) are required; visuals alone would not indicate the narrated conversions’ order, and audio alone would not confirm which on-screen step had occurred.

question:

Determining this order requires audio (tool names, instructions like “invert wedge hashes,” and the “let us summarize” cue) and visual evidence (Preferences window, Save As dialog, and the sequence of on-screen changes to bonds).

question: Reconstruct the timeline. (7) “WATER H2O” is written and the speaker says water is H2O with two hydrogens and one oxygen.
gold_reasoning: The sequence begins with the initial introduction of bond types: visually, a red pen writes “COVALENT” beside a circled 1, while the audio identifies two bond types (event 0), which matches sub-event (1). Next, the speaker explicitly defines covalent bonds as sharing valence electrons, synchronized with the writing “2 ATOMS ARE SHARING VALENCE” (event 1), which is sub-event (2). The discussion then narrows to covalent varieties: the audio explains double bonds share two pairs of electrons while the visual shows “Double Covalent: Sharing 2 pairs of e-” being written (event 2), i.e., sub-event (3). After covalent details, the lesson turns to ionic bonding: the audio defines the ionic bond as electrostatic attraction between ions while the green marker draws a +/− diagram (event 4), sub-event (4). Only after that comparison setup does the speaker, with the “Ionic vs. Covalent” notes still on screen, mention differences in electronegativity will be discussed later and octet rule satisfaction (event 7), sub-event (5). The topic then shifts to molecular formulas, announced in audio and seen as a new page titled “Molecular Formulas” appears (event 8), sub-event (6). Finally, the first example is covered: the audio states “water is of course H2O” while the visual shows “WATER H2O” and the atom counts (event 9), sub-event (7). Therefore the correct chronological order is 1 -> 2 -> 3 -> 4 -> 5 -> 6 -> 7, which corresponds to option B.

question:
Reconstruct the correct chronological order of the following sub-events from the video (use both what is shown and what is said):
(1) The word "PROPORTIONS" appears while the narrator defines a compound as different atoms bonded together.
(2) CO and CO2 diagrams show mass ratios 12:16 and 12:32 as the narrator states CO2 is 73% oxygen and 27% carbon.
(3) A cartoon mole appears with "Return of the Mole!" as the narrator defines one mole as 6.022×10^23.
(4) The slide titled "Empirical Formula" gives the lowest whole-integer ratio definition as the narrator echoes that phrasing.
(5) A beaker fills while the narrator says water’s empirical and molecular formulas are both H2O.
(6) The screen shows HCl values (Cl 3.0, H 2.1) and ΔEN = 0.9 while the narrator begins talking about atomic radius as an average bonding radius.
(7) The "Atomic Radius and Ions" slide appears as the narrator explains cations are smaller than neutral atoms.
gold_reasoning: The earliest segment after the opener is the "PROPORTIONS" title with the spoken compound definition (visual PROPORTIONS + audio definition, event_id 1), so (1) must be first. The same section then moves to the CO vs CO2 diagrams and the narrator explicitly says "by mass, carbon dioxide is 73% oxygen and 27% carbon" (visual mass-ratio diagrams + audio percentages, event_id 1), giving (2) next. The scene then transitions to the mole segment where a cartoon mole appears and the narrator defines 1 mole as 6.022×10^23 (visual mole character + audio definition, event_id 2), so (3) follows. Next, the video introduces the empirical formula slide with the narrator repeating "lowest whole integer numbers" (visual title "Empirical Formula" + audio wording, event_id 4), placing (4) after (3). The water example comes later, with a beaker filling and the narrator stating water has the same empirical and molecular formula, H2O (visual beaker + audio naming H2O, event_id 6), making (5) next. After electronegativity, the video shows the HCl values and ΔEN = 0.9 while the narrator has already shifted to discussing atomic radius as an average bonding radius (visual HCl/ΔEN card + audio about atomic radius, event_id 8), so (6) follows. Finally, the "Atomic Radius and Ions" slide appears with the narrator explaining that cations are smaller than neutral atoms (visual ions slide + audio cation smaller explanation, event_id 10), giving (7) last. The distractors swap intra-law steps or misplace the atomic-radius/HCl card relative to the water example; aligning both the images and the distinct spoken lines rules those out.

question:
Reconstruct the correct chronological order of the following sub-events from the video (use both what is shown and what is said):
(1) The molecular formula H2O2 for hydrogen peroxide is shown while the narrator talks about finding the molecular formula from a given molar mass.
(2) A beaker fills as the narrator states water has the same empirical and molecular formula, H2O.
(3) The HCl example is introduced as the narrator explains how to determine its electronegativity difference.
(4) The screen shows HCl values (Cl 3.0, H 2.1) and ΔEN = 0.9 while the narrator starts discussing atomic radius as an average bonding radius.
(5) Arrows and labels show "Bond Radius Increases Down a Column" as the narrator explains the principal quantum number increasing down a column.
(6) The "Ionization Energy" slide appears while the narrator defines the energy required to remove an electron and its trend across the table.
gold_reasoning: The hydrogen peroxide molecular formula (H2O2) appears during the empirical/molecular section while the narrator emphasizes using a given molar mass to find the molecular formula (visual H2O2 slide + audio instruction, event_id 5), so (1) comes first. Next is the water example with a filling beaker and the narrator stating water’s empirical and molecular formulas are the same (visual beaker + audio "H2O", event_id 6), giving (2). The electronegativity segment then introduces HCl with the narrator explaining how to compute the difference (visual HCl example + audio method description, event_id 7), placing (3). Immediately after, the screen still shows HCl values and ΔEN = 0.9, but the narration has shifted to atomic radius as an average bonding radius (visual HCl/ΔEN card + audio about atomic radius, event_id 8), so (4) follows. The atomic-radius trend visualization with arrows and the narration about principal quantum number increasing down a group comes next (visual arrows/labels + audio trend explanation, event_id 9), giving (5). Finally, the "Ionization Energy" slide appears with narration defining the energy required to remove an electron and its periodic trend (visual ionization energy slide + audio definition/trend, event_id 11), so (6) is last. Distractors either swap the water and peroxide slides or invert the HCl electronegativity and atomic-radius discussions; matching the distinct spoken content with the on-screen visuals rules them out.

question: Reconstruct the correct chronological order of these sub-events around safety checks, setup, and pressure verification (the list is shuffled): (1) A green slide reads "Check for star cracks." (2) The narrator instructs to use flasks that withstand evacuation and to check for damage first. (3) A green slide labeled "Receiver adapter" appears. (4) The narrator says the joints are sealed with vacuum grease and the setup is tested for leaks. (5) A green slide states "Prevent bumping." (6) The narrator describes connecting to the vacuum pump and regulating pressure while stirring for smooth boiling. (7) A green slide lists "Step 8: Open manometer, Record temperature, Check pressure, Close manometer port, Eliminate leaks." (8) The narrator reviews reduced-pressure distillation steps, including heating slowly and collecting fractions.
gold_reasoning: Event 11 first presents the visual safety cue "Check for star cracks" (video_caption), so (1) leads, accompanied by narration about using flasks that can withstand evacuation and checking for damage (audio_caption), placing (2) immediately after. Event 12 then shifts to components: the "Receiver adapter" slide appears (video_caption) for (3), followed by the narrator specifying sealing with vacuum grease and leak testing (audio_caption) for (4). Event 13 continues with boiling behavior: the "Prevent bumping" slide (video_caption) gives (5), and the narrator describes connecting to the vacuum pump, regulating pressure, and stirring for smooth boiling (audio_caption), establishing (6). Finally, Event 14 shows a procedural checklist slide including "Step 8: Open manometer, Record temperature, Check pressure, Close manometer port, Eliminate leaks" (video_caption), so (7) comes next, and the narrator then reviews reduced-pressure distillation steps like heating slowly and collecting fractions (audio_caption), concluding with (8). Both modalities are needed: the sequence of green slides (visual) orders (1), (3), (5), and (7), while the corresponding spoken instructions (audio) are interleaved and must be paired contextually—e.g., leak testing (4) belongs with the receiver adapter segment (3), and the review narration (8) clearly follows the checklist slide (7).

question: Reconstruct the correct timeline by ordering the following sub-events as they occur in the video. Use both what is seen (who is on screen, graphics) and what is heard (specific statements, music cues). Sub-events (shuffled): (1) Mark says both committees are discussing “undecafluorohexanoic acid” and aim to adopt opinions later this year. (2) Suspenseful music plays as the host opens, mentions COVID-19 and EU restrictions, and introduces Mark in Helsinki. (3) The host notes PFHxA is under discussion with a consultation open until September 25 and invites submissions. (4) Mark reports colleagues have worked from home since mid-March and that June virtual committee meetings went well. (5) The host states “In 2019, ECHA proposed restrictions on microplastics,” followed by a brief musical interlude. (6) After being asked about “forever chemicals,” an update is given that a final opinion on one PFAS was adopted in June, with benefits outweighing costs.
gold_reasoning: Chronology requires pairing visuals (who is on screen; overlays) with audio content. First is the opening (event_id 0): we see the dark screen transition to the Earth-in-hexagon and the host in a blue set; the audio has suspenseful orchestral music and the host mentions COVID-19 and EU restrictions and introduces Mark—this corresponds to sub-event (2). Next, we cut to Mark in Helsinki with headset and ChemCon/world-map overlay (event_id 1); he says colleagues worked from home and that June virtual committee meetings went well—sub-event (4). Then the discussion turns to PFAS updates (event_id 3): after the host asks about “forever chemicals,” the speaker states a final opinion on a PFAS was adopted in June with benefits outweighing costs—sub-event (6). After that, still in Mark’s segment (event_id 4), he specifically mentions another PFAS, “undecafluorohexanoic acid,” with opinions targeted later in the year—sub-event (1). Later, the host segment about PFHxA (event_id 7) appears; visually the host is back on the blue backdrop and invites stakeholders to submit info with a consultation open until September 25—sub-event (3). Finally, a short transition where the host says “In 2019, ECHA proposed restrictions on microplastics,” followed by a brief musical interlude (event_id 10)—sub-event (5). Audio alone cannot reliably order the two male voices; the visual switches between the host’s studio and Mark’s Helsinki feed, plus the music cues (events 0 and 10), are needed alongside the spoken content to disambiguate the sequence.

question: Reconstruct the correct chronological order of these sub-events based on the video and narration: (1) The narrator shows the NaCl calculation and asks, "What would be the correct procedure of preparing a one molar solution?" (2) A beaker on a stir plate is used to dissolve salt; the speaker mentions adding 2.92 g to 50 mL and that the solution is ready to be deposited. (3) A pipette dispenses a clear droplet onto a black rectangular substrate in a petri dish. (4) The petri dish is placed into a device with a digital "80" display to dry the sample. (5) The narrator states the droplets have evaporated within 24 hours and flat, square crystals have grown on the glass slide, shown under magnification. (6) The speaker explains adhering the sample to a holder with polymer clay and aligning the crystal top surface for XRD. (7) Diffraction patterns for "NaCl powder" and "NaCl crystal on glass" are presented, and the speaker asks about preferred growth orientation.
gold_reasoning: Event 2 (audio) provides the calculation walkthrough and explicitly asks, "What would be the correct procedure of preparing a one molar solution?" while the visual shows the calculation text, which must precede any lab execution, so (1) is first. Event 3 (audio) describes weighing 2.92 g, preparing 50 mL water, the stirring sound, and concludes the solution is "ready to be deposited"; visuals show stirring—this places (2) immediately after (1). Event 4 (visual) shows a pipette depositing onto a black substrate and then placing the petri dish into a unit reading "80"; the audio here mentions drying at 80 °C, so (3) deposit precedes (4) drying in the same segment. Event 7 (audio) then states the droplets have evaporated within 24 hours and millimeter-sized flat square crystals have grown, matching the microscopy visuals, so (5) follows drying. Event 8 (audio) details adhering the sample with polymer clay and aligning the top surface for XRD at the instrument marked with a radiation hazard (visual), so (6) comes next. Finally, Event 9 shows the diffraction graphs and (audio) introduces measured patterns and asks about preferred orientation, making (7) last. Thus the correct order is 1 -> 2 -> 3 -> 4 -> 5 -> 6 -> 7.

question: Reconstruct the correct chronological order of these sub-events based on the video and narration: (1) The speaker introduces NaCl’s cubic lattice while a labeled sodium chloride container is shown. (2) The narrator says preferential growth will be determined using XRD and mentions growth from a 1 M solution, with ambient electronic music in the background. (3) Sodium chloride crystals are crushed into powder in a mortar and pestle for XRD, with grinding sounds. (4) Powder is carefully spread into an XRD sample holder so the top surface is flush. (5) The speaker notes the powder must remain in the holder when tilted. (6) At the XRD station with a CAUTION: RADIATION HAZARD sign, the speaker describes adhering the glass substrate sample to a holder with polymer clay and aligning its top surface. (7) The narrator introduces measured diffraction patterns and asks about preferred crystal growth orientation.
gold_reasoning: Event 0 begins with an audio introduction to NaCl’s structure while the container is shown, serving as the conceptual start, so (1) is first. Event 1’s audio then outlines the plan—“The preferential growth direction will be determined using X-ray diffraction” and mentions a 1 M solution—with distinct ambient electronic music, indicating early experimental intent, placing (2) next. Event 5 (audio) describes crushing crystals for XRD with audible grinding, which must precede mounting, so (3) follows. Event 6 (audio) then details adding powder to an XRD holder and leveling it flush, accompanied by subtle scraping sounds, making (4) next. Event 7 (audio) explicitly checks that the holder retains powder when tilted, which logically comes after mounting and leveling, giving (5). Event 8 shows the XRD setup (visual CAUTION: RADIATION HAZARD) while the audio explains adhering the glass substrate sample with polymer clay and aligning the top surface, which is done before measurement, so (6) follows. Finally, Event 9 (visual graphs; audio introducing measured patterns and asking about preferred orientation) is the outcome step, making (7) last. Both visuals (container, mortar/pestle, hazard sign, graphs) and audios (introductory explanation, plan with music, grinding/scraping cues, retention check, and final data presentation) are required to anchor this order.

question: Reconstruct the correct chronological order of these sub-events from the distillation tutorial: (1) In the lab, two men talk as one suggests going to someone to demonstrate the process step-by-step. (2) A female narrator defines boiling point while a diagram shows “Atmospheric Pressure equals Vapor Pressure.” (3) A “Choose a heat source” graphic appears as the narrator says they’ll use a Bunsen burner. (4) The Bunsen burner is lit to a steady blue flame while the narrator explains lighting and adjustment. (5) A “Thermometer placement” diagram appears as glassware is clamped into the distillation setup. (6) The narrator concludes, “Let us review the steps,” with step-by-step text on screen.
gold_reasoning: Event 0 (visual: two men in a lab; audio: one proposes going to someone to demonstrate step-by-step) clearly opens the sequence, setting up the tutorial. Event 1 follows with the theoretical foundation (visual: boiling point diagram and boiling flask; audio: female defining boiling point). Event 2 then transitions into setup choices (visual: “Choose a heat source” with burner options; audio: decision to use a Bunsen burner). Event 3 shows the practical lighting (visual: burner lit to a blue flame; audio: instructions on lighting/adjustment), which must come after choosing the burner. Event 5 continues assembly specifics (visual: “Thermometer placement” graphic and clamping; audio: guidance on positioning to ensure proper moistening by vapors). Finally, Event 7 wraps up (visual: step-by-step text; audio: “Let us review the steps”). Determining this order requires both modalities: the visuals provide the diagrams, flame, and assembly shots, while the audio provides the explicit cues like the initial proposal, the definition, the choice of heat source, and the concluding review.

question: Reconstruct the correct chronological order of these assembly and safety sub-events: (1) An iron ring is set up and gauze is placed on it. (2) Liquid is poured into a flask mounted on a stand. (3) The condenser is secured with metal joint clamps. (4) The screen shows “Never heat a closed system” as the narrator warns about sealed setups. (5) The narrator reassures, “it’s not a bomb,” after checking the sidearm. (6) The narrator cautions to adjust water flow to prevent an “unexpected bath.”
gold_reasoning: Event 4 begins with setup: visually the iron ring and gauze are placed, and the audio mentions using an iron ring and gauze, so (1) precedes (2), where we see liquid poured into a flask on the stand while the narrator continues the assembly guidance. Event 5 then advances to securing components (visual: condenser being clamped; audio: “clamp your condenser using the metal joint clamps”), matching (3). Event 6 introduces safety warnings before heating (visual: the yellow “Never heat a closed system” graphic; audio: the hazard explanation), i.e., (4), immediately followed by the same segment’s reassurance (audio: “it’s not a bomb” after checking the sidearm), i.e., (5). Only after assembly and safety checks does Event 7 advise operational cautions, including (6) the audio warning to adjust water flow to prevent an “unexpected bath.” Establishing this sequence requires both modalities: the visuals anchor the ring/gauze placement, pouring, clamping, and the on-screen warning, while the audio provides the specific safety statements and the caution about water flow that time these actions relative to each other.

question:
Reconstruct the correct chronological order of the following sub-events from the video. Use both visuals and narration to decide the sequence.
(1) Two rows of colorful test tubes (bottom row red‑lit) are shown as the speaker explains host–guest complexation and drug‑delivery applications.
(2) On a white screen titled “Solvation,” the speaker defines solvation and notes hydration is solvation by water.
(3) A pale‑pink “Solution” slide with a hydrated Na+ appears as the speaker mentions donor numbers as a quantitative measure of solvation power.
(4) A pink hydration slide stays while the speaker describes a solvation shell and altered ordering around the solute.
(5) A gradient of test tubes is shown while the speaker mentions insoluble oxides and lack of solvation, then references free energy of transfer.
(6) A Na+ with δ‑labeled water molecules is shown as the speaker states solvent polarity is the most important factor.
gold_reasoning: We align each sub-event with specific visuals and audio across events 0, 2, 3, 8, 9, and 12. The video opens in event 0 (00:00:00–00:01:16) with a white screen titled “Solvation” and the narration defining solvation and noting hydration—this is sub-event (2). Event 2 (00:01:55–00:02:41) then shows δ‑labeled water around Na+ while the speaker emphasizes that solvent polarity is the most important factor—sub-event (6). Next, event 3 (00:02:41–00:03:08) is a pink hydration slide as the speaker explains the solvation shell and altered ordering—sub-event (4). Later, event 8 (00:06:37–00:06:57) presents a pale‑pink “Solution” slide while the speaker mentions donor numbers quantifying solvation power—sub-event (3). Event 9 (00:06:57–00:07:23) returns to colorful test tubes and related diagrams as the audio discusses ion-specific behavior like insoluble oxides and references free energy of transfer—sub-event (5). Finally, event 12 (00:08:54–00:09:25) shows two rows of test tubes, with the bottom row red‑lit, as the speaker discusses host–guest complexation and drug‑delivery—sub-event (1). Both the unique slide styles (white intro, pink vs pale‑pink hydration slides, two-row red‑lit test tubes) and the narration topics (definition/hydration, polarity priority, solvation shell, donor numbers, insoluble oxides/free energy, host–guest) are required to fix the timeline. Thus the correct order is 2 -> 6 -> 4 -> 3 -> 5 -> 1.
